command.name: help
command.help:
The <info>help</info> command displays help for a given command:
<info>./symfony help list</info>
You can also output the help as XML by using the <comment>--xml</comment> option:
<info>./symfony help --xml list</info>

option.name: --xml
option.description: To output help as XML

command.name: list
command.help:
The <info>list</info> command lists all commands:
<info>./symfony list</info>
You can also display the commands for a specific namespace:
<info>./symfony list test</info>
You can also output the information as XML by using the <comment>--xml</comment> option:
<info>./symfony list --xml</info>

option.name: --xml
option.description: To output help as XML

option.name: --help
option.description: Display this help message.

option.name: --quiet
option.description: Do not output any message.

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase verbosity of messages.

option.name: --version
option.description: Display this program version.

option.name: --ansi
option.description: Force ANSI output.

option.name: --no-ansi
option.description: Disable ANSI output.

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

command.name: dbal:import
command.description: Import SQL file(s) directly to Database.
command.help: Import SQL file(s) directly to Database.

argument.name: file
argument.description: File path(s) of SQL to be executed.

command.name: dbal:run-sql
command.description: Executes arbitrary SQL directly from the command line.
command.help: Executes arbitrary SQL directly from the command line.

option.name: --depth
option.description: Dumping depth of result set.

command.name: orm:clear-cache:metadata
command.description: Clear all metadata cache of the various cache drivers.
command.help: Clear all metadata cache of the various cache drivers.

command.name: orm:clear-cache:query
command.description: Clear all query cache of the various cache drivers.
command.help: Clear all query cache of the various cache drivers.

command.name: orm:clear-cache:result
command.description: Clear result cache of the various cache drivers.
command.help: Clear result cache of the various cache drivers. If none of the options are defined, all cache entries will be removed.

option.name: --id
option.description: ID(s) of the cache entry to delete (accepts * wildcards).

option.name: --regex
option.description: Delete cache entries that match the given regular expression(s).

option.name: --prefix
option.description: Delete cache entries that have the given prefix(es).

option.name: --suffix
option.description: Delete cache entries that have the given suffix(es).

command.name: orm:convert-d1-schema
command.description: Converts Doctrine 1.X schema into a Doctrine 2.X schema.
command.help: Converts Doctrine 1.X schema into a Doctrine 2.X schema.

argument.name: from-path
argument.description: The path of Doctrine 1.X schema information.

argument.name: dest-path
argument.description: The path to generate your Doctrine 2.X mapping information.

option.name: --from
option.description: Optional paths of Doctrine 1.X schema information.

option.name: --extend
option.description: Defines a base class to be extended by generated entity classes.

option.name: --num-spaces
option.description: Defines the number of indentation spaces

command.name: orm:convert-mapping
command.description: Convert mapping information between supported formats.
command.help:
Convert mapping information between supported formats.
This is an execute <info>one-time</info> command. It should not be necessary for you to call this method multiple times, escpecially when using the <comment>--from-database</comment> flag.
Converting an existing databsae schema into mapping files only solves about 70-80% of the necessary mapping information. Additionally the detection from an existing database cannot detect inverse associations, inheritance types, entities with foreign keys as primary keys and many of the semantical operations on associations such as cascade.
<comment>Hint:</comment> There is no need to convert YAML or XML mapping files to annotations every time you make changes. All mapping drivers are first class citizens in Doctrine 2 and can be used as runtime mapping for the ORM.

argument.name: to-type
argument.description: The mapping type to be converted.

argument.name: dest-path
argument.description: The path to generate your entities classes.

option.name: --filter
option.description: A string pattern used to match entities that should be processed.

option.name: --force
option.description: Force to overwrite existing mapping files.

option.name: --from-database
option.description: Whether or not to convert mapping information from existing database.

option.name: --extend
option.description: Defines a base class to be extended by generated entity classes.

option.name: --num-spaces
option.description: Defines the number of indentation spaces

option.name: --namespace
option.description: Defines a namespace for the generated entity classes, if converted from database.

command.name: orm:ensure-production-settings
command.description: Verify that Doctrine is properly configured for a production environment.
command.help: Verify that Doctrine is properly configured for a production environment.

option.name: --complete
option.description: Flag to also inspect database connection existance.

command.name: orm:generate-entities
command.description: Generate entity classes and method stubs from your mapping information.
command.help:
Generate entity classes and method stubs from your mapping information.
If you use the <comment>--update-entities</comment> or <comment>--regenerate-entities</comment> flags your exisiting code gets overwritten. The EntityGenerator will only append new code to your file and will not delete the old code. However this approach may still be prone to error and we suggest you use code repositories such as GIT or SVN to make backups of your code.
It makes sense to generate the entity code if you are using entities as Data Access Objects only and dont put much additional logic on them. If you are however putting much more logic on the entities you should refrain from using the entity-generator and code your entities manually.
<error>Important:</error> Even if you specified Inheritance options in your XML or YAML Mapping files the generator cannot generate the base and child classes for you correctly, because it doesn't know which class is supposed to extend which. You have to adjust the entity code manually for inheritance to work!

argument.name: dest-path
argument.description: The path to generate your entity classes.

option.name: --filter
option.description: A string pattern used to match entities that should be processed.

option.name: --generate-annotations
option.description: Flag to define if generator should generate annotation metadata on entities.

option.name: --generate-methods
option.description: Flag to define if generator should generate stub methods on entities.

option.name: --regenerate-entities
option.description: Flag to define if generator should regenerate entity if it exists.

option.name: --update-entities
option.description: Flag to define if generator should only update entity if it exists.

option.name: --extend
option.description: Defines a base class to be extended by generated entity classes.

option.name: --num-spaces
option.description: Defines the number of indentation spaces

command.name: orm:generate-proxies
command.description: Generates proxy classes for entity classes.
command.help: Generates proxy classes for entity classes.

argument.name: dest-path
argument.description: The path to generate your proxy classes. If none is provided, it will attempt to grab from configuration.

option.name: --filter
option.description: A string pattern used to match entities that should be processed.

command.name: orm:generate-repositories
command.description: Generate repository classes from your mapping information.
command.help: Generate repository classes from your mapping information.

argument.name: dest-path
argument.description: The path to generate your repository classes.

option.name: --filter
option.description: A string pattern used to match entities that should be processed.

command.name: orm:info
command.description: Show basic information about all mapped entities
command.help: The <info>doctrine:mapping:info</info> shows basic information about which entities exist and possibly if their mapping information contains errors or not.

command.name: orm:run-dql
command.description: Executes arbitrary DQL directly from the command line.
command.help: Executes arbitrary DQL directly from the command line.

option.name: --hydrate
option.description: Hydration mode of result set. Should be either: object, array, scalar or single-scalar.

option.name: --first-result
option.description: The first result in the result set.

option.name: --max-result
option.description: The maximum number of results in the result set.

option.name: --depth
option.description: Dumping depth of Entity graph.

command.name: orm:schema-tool:create
command.description: Processes the schema and either create it directly on EntityManager Storage Connection or generate the SQL output.
command.help: Processes the schema and either create it directly on EntityManager Storage Connection or generate the SQL output.

option.name: --dump-sql
option.description: Instead of try to apply generated SQLs into EntityManager Storage Connection, output them.

command.name: orm:schema-tool:drop
command.description: Drop the complete database schema of EntityManager Storage Connection or generate the corresponding SQL output.
command.help: Processes the schema and either drop the database schema of EntityManager Storage Connection or generate the SQL output. Beware that the complete database is dropped by this command, even tables that are not relevant to your metadata model.

option.name: --dump-sql
option.description: Instead of try to apply generated SQLs into EntityManager Storage Connection, output them.

option.name: --force
option.description: Don't ask for the deletion of the database, but force the operation to run.

option.name: --full-database
option.description: Instead of using the Class Metadata to detect the database table schema, drop ALL assets that the database contains.

command.name: orm:schema-tool:update
command.description: Executes (or dumps) the SQL needed to update the database schema to match the current mapping metadata.
command.help:
The <info>orm:schema-tool:update</info> command generates the SQL needed to synchronize the database schema with the current mapping metadata of the default entity manager.
For example, if you add metadata for a new column to an entity, this command would generate and output the SQL needed to add the new column to the database:
<info>orm:schema-tool:update --dump-sql</info>
Alternatively, you can execute the generated queries:
<info>orm:schema-tool:update --force</info>
Finally, be aware that if the <info>--complete</info> option is passed, this task will drop all database assets (e.g. tables, etc) that are *not* described by the current metadata. In other words, without this option, this task leaves untouched any "extra" tables that exist in the database, but which aren't described by any metadata.

option.name: --complete
option.description: If defined, all assets of the database which are not relevant to the current metadata will be dropped.

option.name: --dump-sql
option.description: Dumps the generated SQL statements to the screen (does not execute them).

option.name: --force
option.description: Causes the generated SQL statements to be physically executed against your database.

command.name: orm:validate-schema
command.help: 'Validate that the mapping files are correct and in sync with the database.'
